reasoning: The critique targets a load-bearing move: modeling AI R&D acceleration via a CES production function and then reading “compute bottlenecks bite late” off CES-shaped diminishing returns/sensitivity plots. If that mapping is wrong, the specific quantitative/qualitative inference about “early stages largely unaffected” is significantly weakened (high centrality). However, the critique mostly argues possibility/plausibility (AI R&D can be thresholdy; queueing/discrete bottlenecks may matter) rather than demonstrating that these alternatives actually imply early hard caps in the relevant regime, so it only moderately refutes the attacked claims (moderate strength). Most statements are reasonable (CES smoothness vs discrete/threshold dynamics is a real concern), though it likely overstates how entirely the post’s conclusion depends on CES given the post’s many non-CES considerations, so correctness is high but not perfect. It is clearly written, focused on one core issue, and contains little filler.
title: CES smoothness ignores threshold bottlenecks, letting compute scarcity bite earlier than claimed
